summary: This document is a chain of emails from July 2019 between defense attorney Michael Bachner and an Assistant U.S. Attorney regarding the Epstein investigation. The emails discuss scheduling a 'reverse proffer' meeting, notifying that a client will invoke the Fifth Amendment before a grand jury, and sharing case materials including the 2007 non-prosecution agreement.

persons.name: Michael Bachner
persons.context: Attorney representing a client involved in the Epstein investigation. He is communicating with federal prosecutors to schedule meetings and formally notifies them that his client will invoke the Fifth Amendment if called before the grand jury.

persons.name: Andrews
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who, along with Michael Bachner, is to attend a meeting with prosecutors at the U.S. Attorney's office. The context suggests they are associated with the defense.

connections.description: Both are scheduled to attend a meeting with prosecutors, indicating they are working together on the defense side of the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Scheduled Reverse Proffer Meeting
events.description: A 'reverse proffer' meeting is scheduled between defense attorney Michael Bachner (and Andrews) and federal prosecutors at the U.S. Attorney's office. The time is set for 3:30pm.

events.title: Prosecutors Provide Case Materials
events.description: Federal prosecutors provide defense attorney Michael Bachner with additional information, including the 2007 Epstein non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and a blank proffer agreement, following a conversation.

events.title: Fifth Amendment Invocation Notified
events.description: Michael Bachner formally notifies prosecutors that if his client is called to testify before the grand jury, she will invoke her Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination.

locations: 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (Office of the U.S. Attorney, Southern District of New York)
39 Broadway, Suite 1610, New York, NY 10006 (Office of Bachner & Associates, PC)
keyFacts: A defense attorney for a client in the Epstein investigation formally notified prosecutors in July 2019 that the client would invoke the Fifth Amendment if called before a grand jury.
Prosecutors provided the defense with the 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA) related to Jeffrey Epstein as part of their discussions.
The emails center on scheduling a 'reverse proffer' meeting, where prosecutors likely present evidence to the defense to encourage cooperation or a plea.
The correspondence highlights active federal investigation and grand jury proceedings in the SDNY Epstein case in July 2019, shortly before Epstein's arrest.
